habitat_description:
The distribution of this species comprises pantropical and warm, temperate regions. Its range size is restricted by high latitudes in the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian oceans.  Nesting areas are found between 25 degrees latitude north and south in beaches of tropical Gulf of Mexico, Bahamas, West Indies, Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, but also on the Atlantic coast of southern and central Florida including the Florida Keys (Lund 1985; Meylan 1992; Natureserve.org). Nesting sites are also found in southeastern Hawaii (Natureserve.org).

The habitat includes areas near the shore line; bays, tidal flats, and sand dunes. Also found in lagoons, tidal rivers, and river mouths. This pelagic species is known to burrow in or using soil (Natureserve.org). Frequently visited sites include a wide range of subtropical and tropical ecosystems such as coral reefs, mangrove-edged estuaries and bays, submerged mud flats, shallow coastal waters, and beds of algae or sea grass (Natureserve.org; CSTC 1999).

Nesting is prevalent in undisturbed beaches with deep sand areas, but also small beaches several meters wide contained in crevices of cliff walls. An example would be a low-energy sand beach with sea grape or saltshrub, along the water line (Natureserve.org). Hatchlings are small and dependent on masses of floating sea plants in the open ocean (CSTC 1999).
